fullText: The show is a lavish spectacle that prioritizes eye candy over storytelling, but the visual feast and energetic performances make it an enjoyable if lightweight experience.
dtliExcerpt: The show is a lavish spectacle that prioritizes eye candy over storytelling, but the visual feast and energetic performances make it an enjoyable if lightweight experience.

keyPhrases.quote: visual feast and energetic performances make it an enjoyable

llmScore.reasoning: Claude: The critic acknowledges significant storytelling weaknesses but finds the production enjoyable due to strong visual elements and performances, suggesting a qualified positive recommendation. | GPT-4o-mini: The review acknowledges enjoyable performances and visuals but critiques the lack of depth in storytelling, leading to a mixed-positive recommendation.

bwwExcerpt: : Disney's new "Aladdin" doesn't quite catch lightning in a bottle - but it lets a pretty nifty genie out of a lamp. That would be James Monroe Iglehart, in the role memorably voiced by Robin Williams in the 1992 animated hit. Every time this Genie's on stage, it's as if "Aladdin" were mainlining Red Bull. Iglehart works so hard during his big number, you fear for his health - that is, when you're not laughing your head off. And then there's the rest of the show...The whole vibe is like a throwb
